 15788                                  ; ****************************************************************************
 15789                                  ; SYSINIT.BIN (MSDOS 6.21 IO.SYS) - RETRO DOS v4.0 by ERDOGAN TAN - 21/10/2022
 15790                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15791                                  ; Last Update: 04/01/2023 (Modified IO.SYS)  ((Previous: 30/12/2022))
 15792                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15793                                  ; Beginning: 03/06/2018 (Retro DOS 3.0), 21/03/2019 (Retro DOS 4.0)
 15794                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15795                                  ; Assembler: NASM version 2.15
 15796                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15797                                  ;	   ((nasm sysinit6.s -l sysinit6.lst -o SYSINIT6.BIN -Z error.txt)) 	
 15798                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15799                                  ; Modified from 'sysinit2.s' (SYSINIT2.BIN) file of Retro DOS v3.0 (6/7/2018)
 15800                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15801                                  ; Derived from 'SYSINIT1.ASM' and 'SYSINIT2.ASM' files of MSDOS 6.0
 15802                                  ; source code by Microsoft, 1991 
 15803                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15804                                  ; Derived from 'SYSINIT.ASM' file of MSDOS 2.0 (IBM PCDOS v2.0) source code
 15805                                  ; by Microsoft, 12/10/1983
 15806                                  ; ****************************************************************************
 15807                                  ; main file: 'retrodos4.s'
 15808                                  ; incbin 'SYSINIT3.BIN' ; (SYINITSEG)
 15809                                  
 15810                                  ; 30/12/2022 - Retro DOS v4.2 
 15811                                  ; Retro DOS v4.0 - 2019
 15812                                  ; SYSINIT (MSDOS 6.21 IO.SYS) draft: 'sysinit3.s' (01/07/2019)
 15813                                   
 15814                                  ; 21/10/2022
 15815                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15816                                  ; This source code (version) is based on SYSINIT source code of disassembled
 15817                                  ; MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS file (SYSINIT.BIN) 
 15818                                  ; Dissassembler: Hex-Rays Interactive Disassembler (IDA)
 15819                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15820                                  ; Binary file splitter & joiner: FFSJ v3.3
 15821                                  
 15822                                  ;--------------------------------------------------------------
 15823                                  ; SYSINIT.TXT (27/01/1983)
 15824                                  ;--------------------------------------------------------------
 15825                                  ;    SYSINIT is  a module linked behind the OEM bios.  It takes
 15826                                  ;over  the  system  initialization  after  the  OEM  bios   has
 15827                                  ;performed any  initialization  it  needs  to  do.   Control is
 15828                                  ;transfered with a long jump to the external  variable  SYSINIT
 15829                                  ;
 15830                                  ;
 15831                                  ;   The OEM  has  the  following  variables declared external:
 15832                                  ;
 15833                                  ;   CURRENT_DOS_LOCATION    WORD
 15834                                  ;
 15835                                  ;This word  contains  the  segment  number of the DOS before it
 15836                                  ;is relocated.  The OEM bios must set this value.
 15837                                  ;
 15838                                  ;   FINAL_DOS_LOCATION      WORD
 15839                                  ;
 15840                                  ;This word contains the segment number of the DOS after SYSINIT
 15841                                  ;moves it.  The OEM bios must set this value.
 15842                                  ;
 15843                                  ;   DEVICE_LIST             DWORD
 15844                                  ;
 15845                                  ;This  double  word  pointer  points  to  the  linked  list  of
 15846                                  ;character and block device drivers.  The  OEM  must  set  this
 15847                                  ;value.
 15848                                  ;
 15849                                  ;   MEMORY_SIZE             WORD
 15850                                  ;
 15851                                  ;This word  contains  the  number  of  RAM  paragraphs.  If the
 15852                                  ;bios doesn't set  this  variable  SYSINIT  will  automatically
 15853                                  ;calculate it.   NOTE:  systems with PARITY checked memory must
 15854                                  ;size memory in the BIOS.  SYSINITs method is to  write  memory
 15855                                  ;and read it back until it gets a mismatch.
 15856                                  ;
 15857                                  ;   DEFAULT_DRIVE           BYTE
 15858                                  ;
 15859                                  ;This is  the initial default drive when the system first comes
 15860                                  ;up.  drive a=0, drive b=1,  etc.   If  the  bios  doesn't  set
 15861                                  ;it then drive a is assumed.
 15862                                  ;
 15863                                  ;   BUFFERS                 BYTE
 15864                                  ;
 15865                                  ;This is  the  default  number of buffers for the system.  This
 15866                                  ;value may be overridden by the user in  the  CONFIG.SYS  file.
 15867                                  ;It is DBed to 2 in SYSINIT it should be greater than 1.
 15868                                  ;
 15869                                  ;   FILES                   BYTE
 15870                                  ;
 15871                                  ;This is  the  default  number  of  files for the system.  This
 15872                                  ;value may be overridden by the user in  the  CONFIG.SYS  file.
 15873                                  ;It is  DBed  to  8 in SYSINIT, values less than 5 are ignored.
 15874                                  ;
 15875                                  ;   SYSINIT                 FAR
 15876                                  ;
 15877                                  ;The entry  point  of  the  SYSINIT  module.  OEM BIOS jumps to
 15878                                  ;this label at the end of its INIT code.
 15879                                  ;
 15880                                  ;   The OEM  has  the  following  variables declared public:
 15881                                  ;
 15882                                  ;   RE_INIT                 FAR
 15883                                  ;
 15884                                  ;This is an entry point which allows the BIOS to do some INIT
 15885                                  ;work  after  the  DOS is initialized.  ALL REGISTERS MUST BE
 15886                                  ;PRESERVED.  On entry DS points to the first available memory
 15887                                  ;(after  the DOS).  DS:0 points to a 100H byte program header
 15888                                  ;prefix which represents  the  "program"  currently  running.
 15889                                  ;This  program  should  be  thought  of  as  the OEM BIOS and
 15890                                  ;SYSINIT taken together.  This is not  a  normal  program  in
 15891                                  ;that  no  memory  is  allocated to it, it is running in free
 15892                                  ;memory.
 15893                                  ;NOTES:
 15894                                  ;     At the time this routine is called SYSINIT occupies the
 15895                                  ;highest 10K of memory ("highest" is determined by the  value
 15896                                  ;of the MEMORY_SIZE variable), DO NOT DO WRITES THERE.
 15897                                  ;     Since this is called AFTER DOS is initialized, you can
 15898                                  ;make system calls.  This also implies that the code for this
 15899                                  ;routine    CANNOT   be   thrown   away   by   use   of   the
 15900                                  ;FINAL_DOS_LOCATION since the DOS has already been moved.
 15901                                  ;     If you don't want  anything done just set this to point
 15902                                  ;at a FAR RET instruction.
 15903                                  
 15904                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15905                                  ; TITLE   BIOS SYSTEM INITIALIZATION
 15906                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15907                                  
 15908                                  ;include version.inc
 15909                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15910                                  
 15911                                  ;FALSE   EQU     0
 15912                                  ;TRUE    EQU     0FFFFh
 15913                                  
 15914                                  ;IBMVER	    EQU     TRUE
 15915                                  ;IBMCOPYRIGHT EQU   FALSE
 15916                                  ;STACKSW    EQU	    TRUE		;Include Switchable Hardware Stacks
 15917                                  ;IBMJAPVER  EQU     FALSE		; If TRUE set KANJI true also
 15918                                  ;MSVER      EQU     FALSE
 15919                                  ;ALTVECT    EQU     FALSE		; Switch to build ALTVECT version
 15920                                  ;KANJI      EQU     FALSE
 15921                                  
 15922                                  ;(MSDOS 6.0, versiona.inc, 1991)
 15923                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15924                                  ;MAJOR_VERSION  EQU	6
 15925                                  ;;MINOR_VERSION	EQU	0	;6.00
 15926                                  ;MINOR_VERSION  EQU	21	;6.21  ; 21/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 15927                                  
 15928                                  ; 22/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0)
 15929                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15930                                  ;MAJOR_VERSION   EQU	5
 15931                                  ;MINOR_VERSION   EQU	0
 15932                                  
 15933                                  ; 01/01/2023 - Retro DOS v4.2 (Modified MSDOS 6.21)
 15934                                  MAJOR_VERSION   EQU	6
 15935                                  MINOR_VERSION   EQU	22
 15936                                  
 15937                                  expected_version equ	(MINOR_VERSION<<8)+MAJOR_VERSION
 15938                                  
 15939                                  ;DOSREVNM equ	00000000b       ; m037 - bits 0-2 = revision number of DOS
 15940                                  				; currently 0.
 15941                                  DOSREVNM equ	00000111b	; [[[ 7 for Retro DOS v4.0 ]]] (21/03/2019)	
 15942                                  DOSINROM equ	00001000B       ; bit 3 of ver flags returned in BH
 15943                                  DOSINHMA equ	00010000B       ; bit 4 of ver flags 
 15944                                  
 15945                                  ;      if1
 15946                                  ;      %OUT  ... for DOS Version 5.00 ...
 15947                                  ;      endif
 15948                                  
 15949                                         ;******************************
 15950                                         ;Each assembler program should:
 15951                                         ;  mov ah,030h                   ;DOS Get Version function
 15952                                         ;  int 021h                      ;Version ret. in AX,minor version first
 15953                                         ;  cmp ax,expected_version       ;ALL utilities should check for an
 15954                                         ;  jne error_handler             ; EXACT version match.
 15955                                         ;******************************
 15956                                  
 15957                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15958                                  ; device definitions
 15959                                  
 15960                                  ;Attribute bit masks
 15961                                  DEVTYP  EQU     8000h           ;Bit 15 - 1  if Char, 0 if block
 15962                                  DEVIOCTL EQU    4000h           ;Bit 14 - CONTROL mode bit
 15963                                  ISFATBYDEV EQU  2000h           ;Bit 13 - Device uses FAT ID bytes, comp media.
 15964                                  ISCIN   EQU     0001h           ;Bit 0 - This device is the console input.
 15965                                  ISCOUT  EQU     0002h           ;Bit 1 - This device is the console output.
 15966                                  ISNULL  EQU     0004h           ;Bit 2 - This device is the null device.
 15967                                  ISCLOCK EQU     0008h           ;Bit 3 - This device is the clock device.
 15968                                  ISIBM   EQU     0010h           ;Bit 4 - This device is special
 15969                                  
 15970                                  ; The device table list has the form:
 15971                                  struc	SYSDEV
 15972 00000000 ????????                .NEXT:		resd 1		;Pointer to next device header
 15973 00000004 ????                    .ATT:		resw 1		;Attributes of the device
 15974 00000006 ????                    .STRAT:		resw 1		;Strategy entry point
 15975 00000008 ????                    .INT:		resw 1		;Interrupt entry point
 15976 0000000A ????????????????        .NAME:		resb 8		;Name of device (only first byte used for block)
 15977                                  .size:
 15978                                  endstruc
 15979                                  
 15980                                  ;Static Reguest Header
 15981                                  struc	SRHEAD
 15982 00000000 ??                      .REQLEN:	resb 1		;Length in bytes of request block
 15983 00000001 ??                      .REQUNIT:	resb 1		;Device unit number
 15984 00000002 ??                      .REQFUNC:	resb 1		;Type of request
 15985 00000003 ????                    .REQSTAT:	resw 1		;Status Word
 15986 00000005 ????????????????                	resb 8		;Reserved for queue links
 15987                                  .size:
 15988                                  endstruc
 15989                                  
 15990                                  ;Status word masks
 15991                                  STERR   EQU     8000H           ;Bit 15 - Error
 15992                                  STBUI   EQU     0200H           ;Bit 9 - Buisy
 15993                                  STDON   EQU     0100H           ;Bit 8 - Done
 15994                                  STECODE EQU     00FFH           ;Error code
 15995                                  WRECODE EQU     0
 15996                                  
 15997                                  ;Function codes
 15998                                  DEVINIT EQU     0               ;Initialization
 15999                                  DINITHL EQU     26              ;Size of init header
 16000                                  DEVMDCH EQU     1               ;Media check
 16001                                  DMEDHL  EQU     15              ;Size of media check header
 16002                                  DEVBPB  EQU     2               ;Get BPB
 16003                                  DEVRDIOCTL EQU  3               ;IOCTL read
 16004                                  DBPBHL  EQU     22              ;Size of Get BPB header
 16005                                  DEVRD   EQU     4               ;Read
 16006                                  DRDWRHL EQU     22              ;Size of RD/WR header
 16007                                  DEVRDND EQU     5               ;Non destructive read no wait (character devs)
 16008                                  DRDNDHL EQU     14              ;Size of non destructive read header
 16009                                  DEVIST  EQU     6               ;Input status
 16010                                  DSTATHL EQU     13              ;Size of status header
 16011                                  DEVIFL  EQU     7               ;Input flush
 16012                                  DFLSHL  EQU     15              ;Size of flush header
 16013                                  DEVWRT  EQU     8               ;Write
 16014                                  DEVWRTV EQU     9               ;Write with verify
 16015                                  DEVOST  EQU     10              ;Output status
 16016                                  DEVOFL  EQU     11              ;Output flush
 16017                                  DEVWRIOCTL EQU  12              ;IOCTL write
 16018                                  
 16019                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16020                                  struc	SYS_FCB
 16021 00000000 ??                      .fcb_drive:	resb 1
 16022 00000001 ????????????????        .fcb_name:	resb 8
 16023 00000009 ??????                  .fcb_ext:	resb 3
 16024 0000000C ????                    .fcb_EXTENT:	resw 1
 16025 0000000E ????                    .fcb_RECSIZ:	resw 1	; Size of record (user settable)
 16026 00000010 ????                    .fcb_FILSIZ:	resw 1	; Size of file in bytes; used with the following
 16027                                                          ; word
 16028 00000012 ????                    .fcb_DRVBP:	resw 1	; BP for SEARCH FIRST and SEARCH NEXT
 16029 00000014 ????                    .fcb_FDATE:	resw 1	; Date of last writing
 16030 00000016 ????                    .fcb_FTIME:	resw 1	; Time of last writing
 16031 00000018 ??                      .fcb_DEVID:	resb 1	; Device ID number, bits 0-5 if file.
 16032                                                          ; bit 7=0 for file, bit 7=1 for I/O device
 16033                                                          ; If file, bit 6=0 if dirty
 16034                                                          ; If I/O device, bit 6=0 if EOF (input)
 16035                                                          ;               Bit 5=1 if Raw mode
 16036                                                          ;               Bit 0=1 if console input device
 16037                                                          ;               Bit 1=1 if console output device
 16038                                                          ;               Bit 2=1 if null device
 16039                                                          ;               Bit 3=1 if clock device
 16040 00000019 ????                    .fcb_FIRCLUS:	resw 1	; First cluster of file
 16041 0000001B ????                    .fcb_CLUSPOS:	resw 1	; Position of last cluster accessed
 16042 0000001D ????                    .fcb_LSTCLUS:	resw 1	; Last cluster accessed and directory
 16043 0000001F ??                                   	resb 1	; pack 2 12 bit numbers into 24 bits...
 16044 00000020 ??                      .fcb_NR:	resb 1	; Next record
 16045 00000021 ????????                .fcb_RR:	resb 4	; Random record
 16046                                  .size:
 16047                                  endstruc
 16048                                  
 16049                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16050                                  ; Field definition for I/O buffer information
 16051                                  
 16052                                  ; 22/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (MSDOS 6.0, BUFFER.INC, 1991)
 16053                                  
 16054                                  struc buffinfo
 16055 00000000 ????                    .buf_next:	resw 1	; Pointer to next buffer in list
 16056 00000002 ????                    .buf_prev:	resw 1	; Pointer to previous buffer in list
 16057 00000004 ??                      .buf_ID:	resb 1	; Drive of buffer (bit 7 = 0)
 16058                                  			; SFT table index (bit 7 = 1)
 16059                                  			; = FFh if buffer free
 16060 00000005 ??                      .buf_flags:	resb 1	; Bit 7 = 1 if Remote file buffer
 16061                                  			;	= 0 if Local device buffer
 16062                                  			; Bit 6 = 1 if buffer dirty
 16063                                  			; Bit 5 = Reserved
 16064                                  			; Bit 4 = Search bit (bit 7 = 1)
 16065                                  			; Bit 3 = 1 if buffer is DATA
 16066                                  			; Bit 2 = 1 if buffer is DIR
 16067                                  			; Bit 1 = 1 if buffer is FAT
 16068                                  			; Bit 0 = Reserved
 16069 00000006 ????????                .buf_sector:	resd 1	; Sector number of buffer (bit 7 = 0)
 16070                                  ; The next two items are often refed as a word (bit 7 = 0)
 16071 0000000A ??                      .buf_wrtcnt:	resb 1	; For FAT sectors, # times sector written out
 16072 0000000B ????                    .buf_wrtcntinc:	resw 1	; "   "     "   , # sectors between each write
 16073 0000000D ????????                .buf_DPB :	resd 1	; Pointer to drive parameters
 16074 00000011 ????                    .buf_fill:	resw 1	; How full buffer is (bit 7 = 1)
 16075 00000013 ??                      .buf_reserved:	resb 1	; make DWORD boundary for 386
 16076                                  .size:
 16077                                  endstruc
 16078                                  
 16079                                  %define buf_offset	dword [buf_sector]
 16080                                  			;For bit 7 = 1, this is the byte
 16081                                  			;offset of the start of the buffer in
 16082                                  			;the file pointed to by buf_ID.  Thus
 16083                                  			;the buffer starts at location
 16084                                  			;buf_offset in the file and contains
 16085                                  			;buf_fill bytes.
 16086                                  
 16087                                  bufinsiz	equ	buffinfo.size ; ; Size of structure in bytes
 16088                                  
 16089                                  
 16090                                  buf_Free	equ	0FFh		; buf_id of free buffer
 16091                                  
 16092                                  ;Flag byte masks
 16093                                  buf_isnet	EQU	10000000B
 16094                                  buf_dirty	EQU	01000000B
 16095                                  ;***
 16096                                  buf_visit	EQU	00100000B
 16097                                  ;***
 16098                                  buf_snbuf	EQU	00010000B
 16099                                  
 16100                                  buf_isDATA	EQU	00001000B
 16101                                  buf_isDIR	EQU	00000100B
 16102                                  buf_isFAT	EQU	00000010B
 16103                                  buf_type_0	EQU	11110001B	; AND sets type to "none"
 16104                                  
 16105                                  buf_NetID	EQU	bufinsiz
 16106                                  
 16107                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16108                                  
 16109                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16110                                  ;**	DPB - Drive Parameter Block
 16111                                  
 16112                                  ; 25/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (MSDOS 6.0, DPB.INC, 1991)
 16113                                  
 16114                                  ;	BUGBUG - this isn't authorative - it's my probably incomplete and
 16115                                  ;	possibly inaccurate deductions from code study... - jgl
 16116                                  ;
 16117                                  ;	The DPB is DOS's main structure for describing block devices.
 16118                                  ;	It contains info about the "Drive" intermingled with info about
 16119                                  ;	the FAT file system which is presumably on the drive.  I don't know
 16120                                  ;	how those fields are used if it's not the FAT file system - BUGBUG
 16121                                  ;
 16122                                  ;	The DPBs are statically allocated and chained off of DPBHead.
 16123                                  ;	Users scan this chain looking for a match on DPB_DRIVE.
 16124                                  ;	The DPBs are built at init time from info in the SYSDEV structure.
 16125                                  
 16126                                  ; 08/06/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0 (MSDOS 3.3, DPB.INC, 24/07/1987)
 16127                                  
 16128                                  ; 12/05/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 16129                                  
 16130                                  struc	DPB
 16131 00000000 ??                      .DRIVE:		resb 1		; Logical drive # assoc with DPB (A=0,B=1,...)
 16132 00000001 ??                      .UNIT:		resb 1		; Driver unit number of DPB
 16133 00000002 ????                    .SECTOR_SIZE:	resw 1		; Size of physical sector in bytes
 16134 00000004 ??                      .CLUSTER_MASK:	resb 1		; Sectors/cluster - 1
 16135 00000005 ??                      .CLUSTER_SHIFT:	resb 1		; Log2 of sectors/cluster
 16136 00000006 ????                    .FIRST_FAT:	resw 1		; Starting record of FATs
 16137 00000008 ??                      .FAT_COUNT:	resb 1		; Number of FATs for this drive
 16138 00000009 ????                    .ROOT_ENTRIES:	resw 1		; Number of directory entries
 16139 0000000B ????                    .FIRST_SECTOR:	resw 1		; First sector of first cluster
 16140 0000000D ????                    .MAX_CLUSTER:	resw 1		; Number of clusters on drive + 1
 16141                                  ;.FAT_SIZE:	resb 1  ; MSDOS 3.3
 16142 0000000F ????                    .FAT_SIZE:	resw 1		; Number of records occupied by FAT
 16143 00000011 ????                    .DIR_SECTOR:	resw 1		; Starting record of directory
 16144 00000013 ????????                .DRIVER_ADDR:	resd 1		; Pointer to driver
 16145 00000017 ??                      .MEDIA:		resb 1		; Media byte
 16146 00000018 ??                      .FIRST_ACCESS:	resb 1		; This is initialized to -1 to force a media
 16147                                  				; check the first time this DPB is used
 16148 00000019 ????????                .NEXT_DPB:	resd 1		; Pointer to next Drive parameter block
 16149 0000001D ????                    .NEXT_FREE:	resw 1		; Cluster # of last allocated cluster
 16150 0000001F ????                    .FREE_CNT:	resw 1		; Count of free clusters, -1 if unknown
 16151                                  .size:
 16152                                  endstruc
 16153                                  
 16154                                  DPBSIZ  EQU     DPB.size	; Size of the structure in bytes
 16155                                  
 16156                                  DSKSIZ  EQU	DPB.MAX_CLUSTER	; Size of disk (temp used during init only)
 16157

 16213                                  ; 25/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0  (MSDOS 6.0, BPB.INC, IOCTL.INC)
 16214                                  
 16215                                  ;**	BIOS PARAMETER BLOCK DEFINITION
 16216                                  ;
 16217                                  ;	The BPB contains information about the disk structure.  It dates
 16218                                  ;	back to the earliest FAT systems and so FAT information is
 16219                                  ;	intermingled with physical driver information.
 16220                                  ;
 16221                                  ;	A boot sector contains a BPB for its device; for other disks
 16222                                  ;	the driver creates a BPB.  DOS keeps copies of some of this
 16223                                  ;	information in the DPB.
 16224                                  ;
 16225                                  ;	The BDS structure contains a BPB within it.
 16226                                  
 16227                                  struc A_BPB
 16228 00000000 ????                    .BPB_BYTESPERSECTOR:	resw	1
 16229 00000002 ??                      .BPB_SECTORSPERCLUSTER:	resb	1
 16230 00000003 ????                    .BPB_RESERVEDSECTORS:	resw	1
 16231 00000005 ??                      .BPB_NUMBEROFFATS:	resb	1
 16232 00000006 ????                    .BPB_ROOTENTRIES: 	resw	1
 16233 00000008 ????                    .BPB_TOTALSECTORS:	resw	1
 16234 0000000A ??                      .BPB_MEDIADESCRIPTOR:	resb	1
 16235 0000000B ????                    .BPB_SECTORSPERFAT:	resw	1
 16236 0000000D ????                    .BPB_SECTORSPERTRACK:	resw	1
 16237 0000000F ????                    .BPB_HEADS:		resw	1
 16238 00000011 ????                    .BPB_HIDDENSECTORS:	resw	1
 16239 00000013 ????                    			resw	1
 16240 00000015 ????                    .BPB_BIGTOTALSECTORS:	resw	1
 16241 00000017 ????                    			resw	1
 16242 00000019 ????????????            			resb	6	; NOTE:  many times these
 16243                                  ;					; 	 6 bytes are omitted
 16244                                  ;					;	 when BPB manipulations
 16245                                  ;					;	 are performed!
 16246                                  .size:
 16247                                  endstruc
 16248                                  
 16249                                  struc A_DEVICEPARAMETERS
 16250 00000000 ??                      .DP_SPECIALFUNCTIONS:	resb	1
 16251 00000001 ??                      .DP_DEVICETYPE:		resb	1
 16252 00000002 ????                    .DP_DEVICEATTRIBUTES:	resw	1
 16253 00000004 ????                    .DP_CYLINDERS:		resw	1
 16254 00000006 ??                      .DP_MEDIATYPE:		resb	1
 16255 00000007 <res 1Fh>               .DP_BPB:		resb	A_BPB.size
 16256 00000026 ????                    .DP_TRACKTABLEENTRIES:	resw	1
 16257 00000028 <res FCh>               .DP_SECTORTABLE:	resb	MAX_SECTORS_IN_TRACK * A_SECTORTABLE.size
 16258                                  endstruc

 16506                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16507                                  ; BIOSTRUC.INC (MSDOS 3.3 - 24/07/1987) 	
 16508                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16509                                  					  ;;Rev 3.30 Modification
 16510                                  ; ROM BIOS CALL PACKET STRUCTURES					  
 16511                                  									  
 16512                                  ;*******************************					  
 16513                                  ;System Service call ( Int 15h )					  
 16514                                  ;*******************************					  
 16515                                  ;Function AH = 0C0h, Return system configuration			  
 16516                                  ;For PC and PCJR on return:						  
 16517                                  ;	(AH)	= 80h							  
 16518                                  ;	(CY)	= 1							  
 16519                                  ;For PCXT, PC PORTABLE and PCAT on return:				  
 16520                                  ;	(AH)	= 86h							  
 16521                                  ;	(CY)	= 1							  
 16522                                  ;For all others:							  
 16523                                  ;	(AH)	= 0							  
 16524                                  ;	(CY)	= 0							  
 16525                                  ;	(ES:BX) = pointer to system descriptor vector in ROS		  
 16526                                  ; System descriptor :							  
 16527                                  ;	DW	xxxx		length of descriptor in bytes,		  
 16528                                  ;				minimum length = 8			  
 16529                                  ;	DB	xx		model byte				  
 16530                                  ;				0FFh	= PC				  
 16531                                  ;				0FEh	= PC/XT, Portable		  
 16532                                  ;				0FDh	= PC/JR 			  
 16533                                  ;				0FCh	= PC/AT				  
 16534                                  ;				0F9h	= Convertable			  
 16535                                  ;				0F8h	= Model 80			  
 16536                                  ;				0E0 thru 0EFh = reserved		  
 16537                                  ;									  
 16538                                  ;	DB	xx		secondary model byte			  
 16539                                  ;				000h	= PC1				  
 16540                                  ;				000h	= PC/XT, Portable		  
 16541                                  ;				000h	= PC/JR 			  
 16542                                  ;				000h	= PC/AT 			  
 16543                                  ;				001h	= PC/AT Model 339		  
 16544                                  ;				003h	= PC/RT				  
 16545                                  ;				000h	= Convertable			  
 16546                                  ;									  
 16547                                  ;	DB	xx		bios revision level			  
 16548                                  ;				00 for first release, subsequent release  
 16549                                  ;				of code with same model byte and	  
 16550                                  ;				secondary model byte require revison level
 16551                                  ;				to increase by one.			  
 16552                                  ;									  
 16553                                  ;	DB	xx		feature information byte 1		  
 16554                                  ;				X0000000 = 1, bios use DMA channel 3	  
 16555                                  ;					 = 0, DMA channel 3 not used	  
 16556                                  ;									  
 16557                                  ;				0X000000 = 1, 2nd Interrupt chip present  
 16558                                  ;					 = 0, 2nd Interrupt chip not present
 16559                                  ;									  
 16560                                  ;				00X00000 = 1, Real Time Clock present	  
 16561                                  ;					 = 0, Real Time Clock not present 
 16562                                  ;									  
 16563                                  ;				000X0000 = 1, Keyboard escape sequence(INT 15h)
 16564                                  ;						called in keyboard interrupt
 16565                                  ;						(Int 09h).		  
 16566                                  ;					 = 0, Keyboard escape sequence not
 16567                                  ;						called. 		  
 16568                                  ;				0000XXXX reserved			  
 16569                                  ;									  
 16570                                  ;	DB	xx		feature information byte 2 - reserved	  
 16571                                  ;									  
 16572                                  ;	DB	xx		feature information byte 2 - reserved	  
 16573                                  ;									  
 16574                                  ;	DB	xx		feature information byte 2 - reserved	  
 16575                                  ;									  
 16576                                  ;	DB	xx		feature information byte 2 - reserved	  
 16577                                  ;									  
 16578                                  
 16579                                  ; 22/03/2019									  
 16580                                  struc ROMBIOS_DESC		; BIOS_SYSTEM_DESCRIPTOR						  
 16581 00000000 ????                    .bios_sd_leng:		resw 1				  
 16582 00000002 ??                      .bios_sd_modelbyte:	resb 1					  
 16583                                  .bios_sd_scnd_modelbyte: 
 16584 00000003 ??                      			resb 1					  
 16585 00000004 ??                      			resb 1					  
 16586 00000005 ??                      .bios_sd_featurebyte1:	resb 1					  
 16587 00000006 ????????                			resb 4					  
 16588                                  endstruc					  
 16589                                  									  
 16590                                  ;FeatureByte1	bit map equates 					  
 16591                                  DMAchannel3		equ 10000000b					  
 16592                                  ScndIntController	equ 01000000b					  
 16593                                  RealTimeClock		equ 00100000b					  
 16594                                  KeyEscapeSeq		equ 00010000b					  
 16595                                  					;;End of Modification

 16697                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16698                                  ; CURDIR.INC (MSDOS 6.0 - 1991) 	
 16699                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16700                                  ; 22/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 16701                                  
 16702                                  ;**	CDS - Current Directory Structure
 16703                                  ;
 16704                                  ; CDS items are used bu the internal routines to store cluster numbers and
 16705                                  ; network identifiers for each logical name.  The ID field is used dually,
 16706                                  ; both as net ID and for a cluster number for local devices. In the case
 16707                                  ; of local devices, the cluster number will be -1 if there is a potential
 16708                                  ; of the disk being changed or if the path must be recracked.
 16709                                  ;
 16710                                  ;	Some pathnames have special preambles, such as
 16711                                  ;
 16712                                  ;		\\machine\sharename\...
 16713                                  ;	For these pathnames we can't allow ".." processing to back us
 16714                                  ;	up into the special front part of the name.  The CURDIR_END field
 16715                                  ;	holds the address of the seperator character which marks
 16716                                  ;	the split between the special preamble and the regular
 16717                                  ;	path list; ".." processing isn't allowed to back us up past
 16718                                  ;	(i.e., before) CURDIR_END
 16719                                  ;	For the root, it points at the leading /. For net
 16720                                  ;	assignments it points at the end (nul) of the initial assignment:
 16721                                  ;	A:/	\\foo\bar	    \\foo\bar\blech\bozo
 16722                                  ;	  ^		 ^		     ^
 16723                                  
 16724                                  DIRSTRLEN	EQU	64+3		; Max length in bytes of directory strings
 16725                                  TEMPLEN 	EQU	DIRSTRLEN*2
 16726                                  
 16727                                  struc 		curdir_list
 16728                                  ; MSDOS 3.3
 16729 00000000 <res 43h>               .cdir_text	resb	DIRSTRLEN	; text of assignment and curdir
 16730 00000043 ????                    .cdir_flags	resw	1		; various flags
 16731 00000045 ????????                .cdir_devptr	resd	1		; local pointer to DPB or net device
 16732 00000049 ????????                .cdir_ID	resw	2		; cluster of current dir (net ID)
 16733 0000004D ????                    .cdir_usr_word	resw	1
 16734 0000004F ????                    .cdir_end	resw	1		; end of assignment
 16735                                  ; MSDOS 6.0
 16736 00000051 ??                      .cdir_type:	resb	1		; IFS drive (2=ifs, 4=netuse)
 16737 00000052 ????????                .cdir_ifd_hdr:	resd	1		; Ptr to File System Header
 16738 00000056 ????                    .cdir_fsda:	resb	2		; File System Dependent Data Area
 16739                                  .size:
 16740                                  endstruc
 16741                                  
 16742                                  curdirlen	EQU	curdir_list.size	; Needed for screwed up
 16743                                  						; ASM87 which doesn't allow
 16744                                  						; Size directive as a macro
 16745                                  						; argument
 16746                                  %define curdir_netID	dword [curdir_list.cdir_ID]
 16747                                  
 16748                                  ;**	Flag values for CURDIR_FLAGS
 16749                                  
 16750                                  ;Flag word masks
 16751                                  curdir_isnet	EQU	1000000000000000B
 16752                                  curdir_isifs	EQU	1000000000000000B
 16753                                  curdir_inuse	EQU	0100000000000000B
 16754                                  curdir_splice	EQU	0010000000000000B
 16755                                  curdir_local	EQU	0001000000000000B

 16757                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16758                                  ; SF.INC (MSDOS 6.0 - 1991) 	
 16759                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16760                                  ; 25/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 16761                                  
 16762                                  ; system file table
 16763                                  
 16764                                  ;**	System File Table SuperStructure
 16765                                  ;
 16766                                  ;	The system file table entries are allocated in contiguous groups.
 16767                                  ;	There may be more than one such groups; the SF "superstructure"
 16768                                  ;	tracks the groups.
 16769                                  
 16770                                  struc	SF
 16771 00000000 ????????                .SFLink:	resd	1
 16772 00000004 ????                    .SFCount:	resw	1		; number of entries
 16773 00000006 ????                    .SFTable:	resw	1		; beginning of array of the following
 16774                                  .size:
 16775                                  endstruc
 16776                                  
 16777                                  ;**	System file table entry
 16778                                  ;
 16779                                  ;	These are the structures which are at SFTABLE in the SF structure.
 16780                                  
 16781                                  struc	SF_ENTRY
 16782 00000000 ????                    .sf_ref_count:	resw	1		; number of processes sharing entry
 16783                                  					;   if FCB then ref count
 16784 00000002 ????                    .sf_mode: 	resw	1		; mode of access or high bit on if FCB
 16785 00000004 ??                      .sf_attr: 	resb	1		; attribute of file
 16786 00000005 ????                    .sf_flags:	resw	1		;Bits 8-15
 16787                                  					; Bit 15 = 1 if remote file
 16788                                  					;	 = 0 if local file or device
 16789                                  					; Bit 14 = 1 if date/time is not to be
 16790                                  					;   set from clock at CLOSE.  Set by
 16791                                  					;   FILETIMES and FCB_CLOSE.  Reset by
 16792                                  					;   other reseters of the dirty bit
 16793                                  					;   (WRITE)
 16794                                  					; Bit 13 = Pipe bit (reserved)
 16795                                  					;
 16796                                  					; Bits 0-7 (old FCB_devid bits)
 16797                                  					; If remote file or local file, bit
 16798                                  					; 6=0 if dirty Device ID number, bits
 16799                                  					; 0-5 if local file.
 16800                                  					; bit 7=0 for local file, bit 7
 16801                                  					;      =1 for local I/O device
 16802                                  					; If local I/O device, bit 6=0 if EOF (input)
 16803                                  					;		Bit 5=1 if Raw mode
 16804                                  					;		Bit 0=1 if console input device
 16805                                  					;		Bit 1=1 if console output device
 16806                                  					;		Bit 2=1 if null device
 16807                                  					;		Bit 3=1 if clock device
 16808 00000007 ????????                .sf_devptr:	resd	1		; Points to DPB if local file, points
 16809                                  					; to device header if local device,
 16810                                  					; points to net device header if
 16811                                  					; remote
 16812 0000000B ????                    .sf_firclus:	resw	1		; First cluster of file (bit 15 = 0)
 16813                                  ;.sf_lstclus:	resw	1 ; *	
 16814 0000000D ????                    .sf_time: 	resw	1		; Time associated with file
 16815 0000000F ????                    .sf_date: 	resw	1		; Date associated with file
 16816 00000011 ????????                .sf_size: 	resd	1		; Size associated with file
 16817 00000015 ????????                .sf_position:	resd	1		; Read/Write pointer or LRU count for FCBs
 16818                                  ;
 16819                                  ; Starting here, the next 7 bytes may be used by the file system to store an
 16820                                  ; ID
 16821                                  ;
 16822 00000019 ????                    .sf_cluspos:	resw	1		; Position of last cluster accessed
 16823 0000001B ????                    .sf_dirsec:	resw	1		; Sector number of directory sector for this file
 16824 0000001D ??                      .sf_dirpos:	resb	1		; Offset of this entry in the above
 16825                                  ;
 16826                                  ; End of 7 bytes of file-system specific info.
 16827                                  ;
 16828 0000001E <res Bh>                .sf_name:	resb	11		; 11 character name that is in the
 16829                                  					; directory entry.  This is used by
 16830                                  					; close to detect file deleted and
 16831                                  					; disk changed errors.
 16832                                  ; SHARING INFO
 16833 00000029 ????????                .sf_chain:	resd	1		; link to next SF
 16834 0000002D ????                    .sf_UID:	resw	1
 16835 0000002F ????                    .sf_PID:	resw	1
 16836 00000031 ????                    .sf_MFT:	resw	1
 16837 00000033 ????                    .sf_lstclus:	resw	1 ; *		; Last cluster accessed
 16838 00000035 ????????                .sf_IFS_HDR:	resd 	1 ; **
 16839                                  .size:
 16840                                  endstruc

 17110                                  
 17111                                  SYSINIT$:
 17112                                  	;IF	STACKSW 
 17113                                  	; include MSSTACK.INC	;Main stack program and data definitions
 17114                                  	; include STKMES.INC	;Fatal stack error message

 17118                                  
 17119                                  ; 05/07/2018
 17120                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17121                                  ; 04/06/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
 17122                                  
 17123                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17124                                  ; 21/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS - SYSINIT)
 17125                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17126                                  
 17127                                  ;	MSStack.inc
 17128                                  ;
 17129                                  ;	Interrupt level 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7,(10, 11, 12, 14, 15 - AT level)
 17130                                  ;	should follow the standard Interrupt Sharing Scheme which has
 17131                                  ;	a standard header structure.
 17132                                  ;	Fyi, the following shows the relations between
 17133                                  ;	the interrupt vector and interrupt level.
 17134                                  ; VEC(Hex)    2  8  9  A  B  C	D  E  70  72  73  74  76  77
 17135                                  ; LVL(Deci)   9  0  1  2  3  4	5  6   8  10  11  12  14  15
 17136                                  ;	MSSTACK module modifies the following interrupt vectors
 17137                                  ;	to meet the standard Interrupt Sharing standard;
 17138                                  ;	  A, B, C, D, E, 72, 73, 74, 76, 77.
 17139                                  ;	Also, for interrupt level 7 and 15, the FirstFlag in a standard header
 17140                                  ;	should be initialized to indicat whether this interrupt handler is
 17141                                  ;	the first (= 80h) or not.  The FirstFlag entry of INT77h's
 17142                                  ;	program header is initialized in STKINIT.INC module.
 17143                                  ;	FirstFlag is only meaningful for interrupt level 7 and 15.
 17144                                  ;
 17145                                  
 17146                                  ;  User specifies the number of stack elements - default = 9
 17147                                  ;						 minimum = 8
 17148                                  ;						 maximum = 64
 17149                                  ;
 17150                                  ;  Intercepts Asynchronous Hardware Interrupts only
 17151                                  ;
 17152                                  ;  Picks a stack from pool of stacks and switches to it
 17153                                  ;
 17154                                  ;  Calls the previously saved interrupt vector after pushing flags
 17155                                  ;
 17156                                  ;  On return, returns the stack to the stack pool
 17157                                  ;
 17158                                  
 17159                                  ; This is a modification of STACKS:
 17160                                  ; 1. To fix a bug which was causing the program to take up too much space.
 17161                                  ; 2. To dispense stack space from hi-mem first rather than low-mem first.
 17162                                  ;    . Clobbers the stack that got too big instead of innocent stack
 17163                                  ;    . Allows system to work if the only stack that got too big was the most
 17164                                  ;      deeply nested one
 17165                                  ; 3. Disables NMI interrupts while setting the NMI vector.
 17166                                  ; 4. Does not intercept any interupts on a PCjr.
 17167                                  ; 5. Double checks that a nested interrupt didn't get the same stack.
 17168                                  ; 6. Intercepts Ints 70, 72-77 for PC-ATs and other future products
 17169                                  
 17170                                  		;EVEN
 17171                                  ;align 2
 17172                                  		; 21/10/2022
 17173                                  
 17174 00000000 0000                    		dw	0	; spare field but leave these in order
 17175 00000002 0000                    stackcount:	dw	0
 17176 00000004 0000                    stackat: 	dw	0
 17177 00000006 0000                    stacksize:	dw	0
 17178 00000008 0000                    stacks:		dw	0
 17179 0000000A 0000                    		dw	0
 17180                                  
 17181 0000000C [0800]                  firstentry:	dw	stacks
 17182 0000000E [4800]                  lastentry:	dw	stacks+(defaultcount*entrysize)-entrysize
 17183 00000010 [4800]                  nextentry:	dw	stacks+(defaultcount*entrysize)-entrysize
 17184                                  
 17185                                  ;***********************************************************************
 17186                                  ; THESE ARE THE INDIVIDUAL INTERRUPT HANDLERS
 17187                                  
 17188                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17189                                  
 17190 00000012 00000000                old02:	dd	0
 17191                                  
 17192                                  int02:
 17193                                  
 17194                                  ; *********************************************************************
 17195                                  ;
 17196                                  ; this is special support for the pc convertible / nmi handler
 17197                                  ;
 17198                                  ;	on the pc convertible, there is a situation where an nmi can be 
 17199                                  ;	caused by using the "out" instructions to certain ports. when this
 17200                                  ;	occurs, the pc convertible hardware *guarantees* that **nothing** 
 17201                                  ;	can stop the nmi or interfere with getting to the nmi handler. this
 17202                                  ;	includes other type of interrupts (hardware and software), and
 17203                                  ;	also includes other type of nmi's. when any nmi has occured,
 17204                                  ;	no other interrtupt (hardware, software or nmi) can occur until
 17205                                  ;	the software takes specific steps to allow further interrupting.
 17206                                  ;
 17207                                  ;	for pc convertible, the situation where the nmi is generated by the
 17208                                  ;	"out" to a control port requires "fixing-up" and re-attempting. in
 17209                                  ;	otherwords, it is actually a "restartable exception". in this
 17210                                  ;	case, the software handler must be able to get to the stack in
 17211                                  ;	order to figure out what instruction caused the problem, where
 17212                                  ;	it was "out"ing to and what value it was "out"ing.  therefore,
 17213                                  ;	we will not switch stacks in this situation. this situation is
 17214                                  ;	detected by interrogating port 62h, and checking for a bit value
 17215                                  ;	of 80h. if set, *****do not switch stacks*****.
 17216                                  ;
 17217                                  ; *********************************************************************
 17218                                  
 17219 00000016 50                      	push	ax
 17220 00000017 06                      	push	es
 17221 00000018 B800F0                  	mov	ax,0F000h
 17222 0000001B 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 17223                                  	; 02/11/2022
 17224 0000001D 26803EFEFFF9            	cmp	byte [es:0FFFEh],0F9h ; mdl_convert ; check if convertible
 17225 00000023 07                      	pop	es
 17226 00000024 750C                    	jne	short normal02
 17227                                  
 17228 00000026 E462                    	in	al,62h		; PC/XT PPI port C. Bits:
 17229                                  				; 0-3: values of DIP switches
 17230                                  				; 5: 1=Timer 2 channel out
 17231                                  				; 6: 1=I/O channel check
 17232                                  				; 7: 1=RAM parity check error occurred.
 17233 00000028 A880                    	test	al,80h
 17234 0000002A 7406                    	jz	short normal02
 17235                                  special02:
 17236 0000002C 58                      	pop	ax
 17237 0000002D 2EFF2E[1200]            	jmp	far [cs:old02]
 17238                                  normal02:
 17239 00000032 58                      	pop	ax
 17240 00000033 E81101                  	call	do_int_stacks
 17241 00000036 [1200]                  	dw	old02
 17242

 17471                                  ;********************************************************************
 17472                                  
 17473                                  ; do interrupt stack switching. the fake return address holds
 17474                                  ; a pointer to the far-pointer of the actual interrupt
 17475                                  ; service routine
 17476                                  
 17477                                  ; 21/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0 SYSINIT)
 17478                                  ; 21/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 17479                                  
 17480                                  ;allocbyte   equ 0
 17481                                  ;intlevel    equ 1
 17482                                  ;savedsp     equ 2
 17483                                  ;savedss     equ 4

 17489                                  do_int_stacks:
 17490 00000147 50                      	push	ax
 17491 00000148 55                      	push	bp
 17492 00000149 06                      	push	es
 17493 0000014A 2E8E06[0A00]            	mov	es,[cs:stacks+2]	; Get segment of stacks
 17494 0000014F 2E8B2E[1000]            	mov	bp,[cs:nextentry]	; get most likely candidate
 17495 00000154 B001                    	mov	al,allocated ; 1
 17496                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17497                                  	;xchg	[es:bp+allocbyte],al 
 17498                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17499 00000156 26864600                	xchg	[es:bp],al		; grab the entry
 17500 0000015A 3C00                    	cmp	al,free ; 0		; still avail?
 17501 0000015C 7551                    	jne	short notfree02
 17502                                  
 17503 0000015E 2E832E[1000]08          	sub	word [cs:nextentry],entrysize ; set for next interrupt
 17504                                  
 17505                                  found02:
 17506 00000164 26896602                	mov	[es:bp+savedsp],sp	; save sp value

 17508

 17510

 17512                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17513                                  	;mov	bp,[es:bp+6]

 17515                                  	;cmp	[es:bp+0],ax	
 17516 00000172 26394600                	cmp	[es:bp],ax		; check for offset into table
 17517 00000176 7544                    	jne	short foundbad02
 17518                                  
 17519                                  	; 02/07/2023 (MSDOS 6.21 SYSINIT code)
 17520 00000178 8CC0                    	mov	ax,es			; point ss,sp to the new stack
 17521 0000017A 8EC5                    	mov	es,bp
 17522 0000017C 89E5                    	mov	bp,sp
 17523 0000017E 8B6E06                  	mov	bp,[bp+6]
 17524 00000181 8ED0                    	mov	ss,ax
 17525 00000183 8CC4                    	mov	sp,es
 17526 00000185 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 17527 00000187 2E8B6E00                	mov	bp,[cs:bp]
 17528                                  
 17529                                  	; 21/10/2022 (MSDOS 5.0 SYSINIT code)
 17530                                  	;push    bp
 17531                                  	;mov     bp,sp
 17532                                  	;mov     ax,[bp+8]
 17533                                  	;pop     bp
 17534                                  	;push    es
 17535                                  	;pop     ss

 17537                                  	;mov     bp,ax
 17538                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17539                                  	;;mov	bp,[cs:bp+0]	
 17540                                  	;mov	bp,[cs:bp]	
 17541

 17543                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17544 0000018C 2EFF5E00                	call	far [cs:bp]		;  which will iret back to here
 17545                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17546                                  	;call	far [cs:bp+0]
 17547                                  
 17548 00000190 89E5                    	mov	bp,sp			; retrieve the table offset for us
 17549                                  	; 11/12/2022

 17551                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17552                                  	;mov	bp,[es:bp+0]

 17554 0000019A 268B6602                	mov	sp,[es:bp+savedsp]
 17555                                  
 17556                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17557                                  	;mov	byte [es:bp+allocbyte],free ; free the entry
 17558                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17559 0000019E 26C6460000              	mov	byte [es:bp],free ; 0
 17560 000001A3 2E892E[1000]            	mov	[cs:nextentry],bp	; setup to use next time
 17561                                  
 17562 000001A8 07                      	pop	es
 17563 000001A9 5D                      	pop	bp			; saved on entry
 17564 000001AA 58                      	pop	ax			; saved on entry
 17565 000001AB 83C402                  	add	sp,2
 17566 000001AE CF                      	iret				; done with this interrupt

 17568                                  notfree02:

 17570 000001B1 7404                    	je	short findnext02	;  no, continue

 17600                                  	; 21/10/2022

 17604 000001D8 B001                    	mov	al,allocated

 17611

 17613 000001E4 7404                    	je	short inuse		;  no, check the next one
 17614

 18927                                  ; It will either be relocated to low memory, above the DOS data structures,
 18928                                  ; or else it will be located in HiMem, in which case a stub with the DOS
 18929                                  ; code entry points will be located in low memory. Dos_segreinit is used
 18930                                  ; to tell the DOS data where the code has been placed, and to install the
 18931                                  ; low memory stub if necessary. If the DOS is going to go into HiMem, we
 18932                                  ; must first initialize it in its present location and load the installable
 18933                                  ; device drivers. Then, if a HiMem driver has been located, we can actually
 18934                                  ; relocate the DOS code into HiMem.
 18935                                  ;
 18936                                  ; For ROMDOS, if DOS=HIGH is indicated, then we need to call dos_segreinit
 18937                                  ; to install the low memory stub (this must be done before allowing any
 18938                                  ; device drivers to hook interrupt vectors). Otherwise, we don't need to 
 18939                                  ; call dos_segreinit at all, since the interrupt vector table has already 
 18940                                  ; been patched.

 19254                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 19255                                  
 19256                                  ;   Once we get to this point, the above code, which is below "retry"
 19257                                  ;   in memory, can be trashed (and in fact is -- see references to retry
 19258                                  ;   which follow....)
 19259                                  
 19260                                  retry:
 19261 00000780 BA[BC45]                	mov	dx,commnd	; now pointing to file description
 19262                                  
 19263                                  ; we are going to open the command interpreter and size it as is done in
 19264                                  ; ldfil. the reason we must do this is that sysinit is in free memory. if
 19265                                  ; there is not enough room for the command interpreter,exec will probably
 19266                                  ; overlay our stack and code so when it returns with an error sysinit won't be
 19267                                  ; here to catch it. this code is not perfect (for instance .exe command
 19268                                  ; interpreters are possible) because it does its sizing based on the
 19269                                  ; assumption that the file being loaded is a .com file. it is close enough to
 19270                                  ; correctness to be usable.
 19271                                  
 19272                                  ; first, find out where the command interpreter is going to go.
 19273                                  
 19274 00000783 52                      	push	dx		; save pointer to name
 19275 00000784 BBFFFF                  	mov	bx,0FFFFh
 19276 00000787 B448                    	mov	ah,48h	; ALLOC
 19277 00000789 CD21                            int     21h             ; get biggest piece
 19278 0000078B B448                    	mov	ah,48h	; ALLOC
 19279 0000078D CD21                    	int	21h		; second time gets it
 19280 0000078F 726B                    	jc	short memerrjx	; oooops
 19281                                  
 19282 00000791 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 19283 00000793 B449                    	mov	ah,49h	; DEALLOC
 19284 00000795 CD21                    	int	21h		; give it right back
 19285 00000797 89DD                    	mov	bp,bx
 19286                                  
 19287                                  ; es:0 points to block,and bp is the size of the block in para.
 19288                                  
 19289                                  ; we will now adjust the size in bp down by the size of sysinit.
 19290                                  ; we need to do this because exec might get upset if some of the exec
 19291                                  ; data in sysinit is overlayed during the exec.
 19292                                  
 19293                                  	; 22/10/2022
 19294                                  	; (MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS SYSINIT:083Bh)
 19295 00000799 8B1E[9402]                      mov     bx,[MEMORY_SIZE] ; get location of end of memory
 19296 0000079D 8CC8                    	mov	ax,cs		 ; get location of beginning of sysinit
 19297                                  
 19298                                  ; Note that the "config_wrkseg" environment data is a segment in
 19299                                  ; unallocated memory (as of the Dealloc of [area], above). This is ideal
 19300                                  ; in one sense, because Exec is going to make a copy of it for COMMAND.COM
 19301                                  ; anyway, and no one has responsibility for freeing "config_wrkseg". But
 19302                                  ; we need to make sure that there's no way Exec will stomp on that data
 19303                                  ; before it can copy it, and one way to do that is to make the available
 19304                                  ; memory calculation even more "paranoid", by subtracting "config_wrkseg"
 19305                                  ; from the "memory_size" segment value (which is typically A000h) instead
 19306                                  ; of the current sysinit CS....
 19307                                  ;
 19308                                  ; The reason I use the term "paranoid" is because this code should have
 19309                                  ; slid the data required by Exec up to the very top of memory, because as
 19310                                  ; it stands, you have to have sizeof(COMMAND.COM) PLUS 64K to load just
 19311                                  ; COMMAND.COM (64k is about what sysinit, and all the goop above sysinit,
 19312                                  ; consumes). Now it's just a little worse (65K or more, depending on
 19313                                  ; the size of your CONFIG.SYS, since the size of the environment workspace
 19314                                  ; is determined by the size of CONFIG.SYS.... -JTP

 19731                                  ; procedure : TryToMovDOSHi
 19732                                  ;

 20154                                  
 20155                                  ; BUGBUG -- 5 Aug 92 -- chuckst -- Allocating space for DOS
 20156                                  ;	  using DOS itself causes an arena to be generated.
 20157                                  ;	  Unfortunately, certain programs (like PROTMAN$)
 20158                                  ;	  assume that the device drivers are loaded into
 20159                                  ;	  the first arena. For this reason, MagicDrv's
 20160                                  ;	  main device driver header arena is manually
 20161                                  ;	  truncated from the arena chain, and the space
 20162                                  ;	  for DOS is allocated using the following
 20163                                  ;	  simple code, which also assumes that the
 20164                                  ;	  first arena is the free one where DOS's low
 20165                                  ;	  stub will go.
 20166                                  ;
 20167                                  ; M012 : BEGIN
 20168                                  
 20169                                  	; 23/10/2022
 20170                                  update_arena:
 20171 00000A18 1E                      	push	ds ; ds = cs
 20172 00000A19 57                      	push	di
 20173 00000A1A 51                      	push	cx
 20174 00000A1B 52                      	push	dx
 20175                                  	; 23/10/2022
 20176                                  	;lds	di,[cs:DOSINFO]			; get ptr to DOS var
 20177                                  	; 11/12/2022
 20178                                  	; ds = cs 
 20179 00000A1C C53E[6D02]              	lds	di,[DOSINFO] ; 27/03/2019	
 20180 00000A20 4F                      	dec	di
 20181 00000A21 4F                      	dec	di				; Arena head is immediately
 20182                                  						;  before sysvar
 20183 00000A22 8E05                    	mov	es,[di]				; es = arena head
 20184                                  	;mov	cx,[es:ARENA.SIZE]		; cx = total low mem size
 20185 00000A24 268B0E0300              	mov	cx,[es:3]
 20186 00000A29 39D9                    	cmp	cx,bx				; is it sufficient ?
 20187 00000A2B 7227                    	jb	short FatalErr			; no, fatal error
 20188                                  
 20189                                  	;mov	dl,[es:ARENA.SIGNATURE]
 20190 00000A2D 268A160000              	mov	dl,[es:0]
 20191 00000A32 8CC0                    	mov	ax,es
 20192 00000A34 01D8                    	add	ax,bx				; ax = new arena head
 20193 00000A36 8905                    	mov	[di],ax				; store it in DOS data area
 20194 00000A38 8ED8                    	mov	ds,ax
 20195                                  	;mov	[ARENA.SIGNATURE],dl		; type of arena
 20196 00000A3A 88160000                	mov	[0],dl
 20197                                  	;mov	word [ARENA.OWNER],0		; free
 20198 00000A3E C70601000000            	mov	word [1],0
 20199 00000A44 29D9                    	sub	cx,bx				; size of the new block
 20200                                  	;mov	[ARENA.SIZE],cx			; store it in the arena
 20201 00000A46 890E0300                	mov	[3],cx
 20202 00000A4A 8CC0                    	mov	ax,es				; return seg to the caller
 20203                                  	; 23/10/2022
 20204                                  	;; 24/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (ORG 0)	; Take care ORG 30h of
 20205 00000A4C 83E803                  	sub	ax,3				;  BIOS code
 20206 00000A4F 5A                      	pop	dx
 20207 00000A50 59                      	pop	cx
 20208 00000A51 5F                      	pop	di
 20209 00000A52 1F                      	pop	ds ; ds = cs
 20210 00000A53 C3                      	retn
 20211                                  ;
 20212                                  ; M012 : END
 20213                                  ;
